title: loch fyne skiff takes shape in former milking parlour
story: Ken MacTaggartUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsWork is well underway on the construction of Argyll’s latest coastal rowing boat, now that the coronavirus advice permits limited team work.The hull of the Upper Loch Fyne Coastal Rowing Club’s skf is emerging rapidly in the old milking parlour of Glenshellish farm, Glenbranter.A team of volunteers led by Neil Wilson is assembling the boat, which comes in kit form but requires additional parts to be made. Volunteer helpers including Patrick Gibb from Strachur, Martyn and Robin Webster, Terry Muirhead-Smith and Derek Anstee of Inveraray.Early October is expected to see a big event – the -foot hull finally turned right way up, marking the half-way point in its construction.The wooden sections came largely pre-cut and shaped by Jordan Boats of Somerset, ready to be assembled locally around a #hog# template using woodworking tools and an epoxy binder. With the main build phase over, she next requires seats and gunwales, not to mention a paint job and a set of oars.When complete the skf will likely be launched at Strachur. It is to be crewed by a team of four rowers and a coxswain.The boat will be named #Mrs McPhun# after the Strachur woman who thought she was widowed by the hanging of her husband Archie McPhun for murder at Inveraray. As Mrs McPhun, their child and the body were being rowed back to Strachur for burial, Archie’s ‘corpse’ groaned, and he was resuscitated. He lived on for some years, albeit with a crooked neck!In recognition of the expected funeral that happily never happened, the skf will be painted black.The Upper Loch Fyne Coastal Rowing Club was set up in Inveraray two years ago with the aim of building and operating a St Ayles skf on the upper reaches of the loch.The club is a member of the Scottish Coastal Rowing Association , which encourages boat building, rowing and racing of coastal rowing boats around the Scottish Coastline. Most follow the design of the St Ayles skf, which emerged in Anstruther based on the traditional Fair Isle skf, and the Scottish community rowing regattas that were traditionally popular.The kit-built boat greatly reduces the cost to a community and, as they are a standard design, they can be fairly raced in rowing against one another. It quickly became a remarkable success, attracting worldwide attention and creating its own boating class association, St Ayles Skf International . There are now over  St Ayles skfs operating around Scotland’s coast and abroad, including over a dozen in Argyll and others in the Netherlands, USA and Australia.The SCRA now has over  member clubs around the Scottish Coast and on large freshwater lochs.The Upper Loch Fyne Coastal Rowing Club, which aims to promote community spirit, learning and purposeful activity for young and old, is open to new members – to help maintain the boat, and potential rowers and navigators keen to learn nautical skills.For further information about the rowing club please contact Martyn Webster at martyn@martynwebster .For club membership or purchasing a share in the boat please contact Terry Muirhead-Smith at terrymuirheadsmith@hotmail .PICS:. no-a_LochFyneSkfNeil Wilson at work on the keel, watched by Robin Webster. no-a_LochFyneSkf. no-a_LochFyneSkf

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirThe fiasco that is the A   Rest and be Thankful is an apt metaphor for the ineptitude of the Scottish government and its handling of issues as erse as transport, the economy, education and health matters.R Finlay, ArdrishaigSir,With regard to your interesting article on routes into Argyll proposed by transport Scotland I see no mention of a tunnel. Surely the simplest solution would be a tunnel from Arrochar to Butterbridge, or from Ardgarten to Butterbridge. From Arrochar may be better as the route is more of a straight line.As a former resident of Tarbert now living in Taynuilt I now live less than  miles from a tunnel into and below a hillside at Loch Awe, Ben Cruachan. I refer of course to the tunnel constructed in  with less sophisticated tools than available now.I have also seen an article on the building of tunnels for carrying water from Loch Katrine to Glasgow, much earlier than , again using more primitive equipment. In addition to those tunnels look at the construction of the railways during the railway early years. There are examples of tunnelling all over the world where knowledge could be given to the Scottish government.Cost should not be an issue, as it seems none is being spared at present to no avail.Dugald McDougall, TaynuiltSir,Many years ago I suggested, to an MP, option seven in the list of options being considered in the list released by the Scottish Government.I also pointed out that the bridging of the Loch Fyne narrows at Port Ann could be used to generate hydro power by incorporating hydro tunnels at the base of the crossing and thus provide income to alleviate costs, while the same time reducing travels costs for commercial and private users and consequently help the environment by reducing pollution.I received favourable opinion from a prominent firm of civil engineers and a #like# from a government official. To give that person credit, however, there were very many more pressing problems.I also note that the simplest idea I have since offered – that of a tunnel through the saddle to connect the ends of the existing military roads below and on each side of the Rest and thereafter, upgrading the old military road to A road standard is not even considered.This begs the question why is  Government in such a mountainous region of Scotland so averse to tunnels In the time since I made such suggestions, more than enough money has been drained away in making repairs.Capt Jim Currie, former Tarbert harbour masterScotland has around , older military veterans and Age Scotland believes that many go without the assistance available to them, such as priority healthcare for conditions linked to their service, help with dental and eye care, housing and financial support.We have launched a revamped version of our popular free #Veterans# Guide to Later Le in Scotland#.The guide features information about support and opportunities available to every older person in Scotland, plus content specically for British Armed Forces veterans including regulars, reservists, National Servicemen and merchant navy who have sailed in support of a British military operation.It is most relevant to veterans aged  plus, but much of the content will be of interest to veterans aged -, regardless of how long ago, or for how long they served.If you are aged  or older, live in Scotland and have served in the armed forces, the guide will be most relevant to you. It doesn’t matter how long ago, or for how long, you served: you may have had a military career, a short period of national service, been a reservist, or even supported a military operation with the merchant navy.Many people we’ve met through our Veterans’ Project left the armed forces with little or no support for readjusting to civilian le. Today, the military is more proactive in supporting that transition, but older veterans it seems were, by and large, left to it.Our guide aims to ensure veterans have a better experience when making the transition to later le.Veterans and their families can request a free paper guide by calling Age Scotland on     or visiting www.age.scot veteransguide. It is also available as a download.Doug Anthoney, Age Scotland Veterans’ Project co-ordinator

title: heathers treks tarbert castle and mealdarroch circular
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsHeather’s Treks: Bruce’s castle and Fyne views.This iation of an old time favourite encompasses history, fabulous views up Loch Fyne and a chance to enjoy the natural anchorage and bustling fishing village of Tarbert.The walk starts opposite Tarbert Parish Church, which stands proudly over the village’s western aspect. Many a coin has been thrown down its banks to children by newlyweds and the building is a fine example of Georgian architecture. And you wouldn’t wish to visit Tarbert without exploring the remains of Tarbert Castle. Here Robert the Bruce undertook major works in  to forty and enlarge it in order to protect his territory from the Lord of the Isles. However, it was not until the late th Century that James IV added the Tower House, the remains of which give the castle its main outline today. Above Tarbert paths and tracks open up grand views and are worth the effort of the steep climbs.. Turn left out of the car park in front of the church. Follow the road for m and cross carefully over to the seafront. Continue towards the pier, which once was crowded by jostling herring boats and piled high with wooden fish boxes as the catch of the day was sold on. your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe A trunk road at the Rest and be Thankful re-opened under traffic light control at around .am on Thursday October  following a safety inspection.Heavy rain since the previous Sunday night prompted the closure of the road as a safety precaution, with all traffic erted via the old military roadlocal ersion route, which runs parallel to the A through Glen Croe, while teams carefully monitored the hillside.The longer road ersion via Crianlarich and Dalmally was implemented early on Wednesday morning as a further precaution due to a blocked surface water channel above the OMR, however this was cleared and the OMR was able to re-open at .am on Wednesday.An early daylight inspection of the A and the hillside by geotechnical experts this morning enabled the road to be re-opened.Teams estimate around mm of rain fell in the area since Sunday night.Further heavy rain is forecast in the coming days and teams from trunk road management firm BEAR Scotland will continue to carefully monitor the hillside and assess the route on a daily basis to determine whether it is safe to remain in operation.The OMR is being maintained in a state of readiness as a local ersion route should the A at the Rest be closed.Engineers are continuing with mitigation work in the area including the installation of a debris pit, debris catch-fence and stabilisation work in the steep channel above the slope.Eddie Ross of BEAR Scotland said #We’re leading on a safety-first approach with teams ready to mobilise use of the OMR local ersion quickly to ensure road users can safely travel through Glen Croe should the A be closed as a precaution.#We’ll endeavour to do all we can to keep disruption to a minimum. On her first stop in Scotland, at an innshe meets the owner , and her plans suddenly change.The cast and crew stayed on location during the six-week shoot at Drimsynie Holiday Park, and among the locations to feature in the film are Lochgilphead, the George Hotel in Inveraray, the Rest and be Thankful, Kilmorich Church, Cairndow and the Lodge on Loch Goil.The romantic comedy was funded by the National Lottery through Screen Scotland’s Production Growth Fund.Argyll is no stranger to movies of all shapes and sizes being shot here # think Ring of Bright Water, Restless Natives, The Water Horse, The Eagle and Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom and many more.#Argyll looks fantastic on screen,# said Jenni Steele, Film and Creative Industries Manager at VisitScotland, #and this is another welcome opportunity to engage with an international audience and keep Scotland front of mind for potential visitors to travel when they can do so.#Councillor Alastair Redman, policy lead for economic growth, added: #We are working hard to make sure it is as attractive and as simple as possible for productions to come to Argyll and Bute, and I’m pleased that it remains a popular location.#There is a dedicated website, www.filminargyll which provides regularly updated information to anyone considering Argyll and Bute as a set location.#Then Came You# is available now on ious online streaming services.

title: jimmy-curran-book-published-galashiels-athletics-coach
story: A NEW biography about a remarkable Borders sporting figure is set to race onto bookshelves this autumn.Jimmy Curran: Scotlands Greatest Athletics Coach, by Craig Statham, tells the story of Jimmy Curran, who was born in Galashiels in , fought in the Second Boer War, emigrated to the USA and trained  Olympic athletes.As an amateur runner at the beginning of the th century, winning the prestigious Hawick Border Mile Championship, Curran would train in the Galashiels cemetery.ldquoThere were no tracks anywhere in Scotland apart from in the bigger towns and cities, so he used the graveyard in Galashiels, said Mr Statham.ldquoAt that time they would run distances in yards, so the equivalent of the m was the  yards, and the cemetery I think was  yards.ldquoIt was almost perfect and it was almost a circle, so he would use that to train when he was younger.Mr Statham, who also works at the National Library of Scotland, said: ldquoJimmy was probably the best half-miler in the UK, up until about , when he emigrated to the United States.ldquoYou could make substantial amounts of money running in the States at that time he initially worked at the University of Pennsylvania as a trainer under a chap called Mike Murphy, and then got a job at the Mercersburg Academy.Having already trained one Olympic champion ndash Wyndham Halswelle ndash before he moved to the USA, Curran went on to train a further  Olympic athletes, five of whom won gold.He was coach for  years at Mercersburg Academy, a school whose students at the time included actor Jimmy Stewart and President Calvin Coolidgersquos son John, and its racetrack is still named after him.ldquoHersquos almost a legend in that Pennsylvania area, said Mr Statham.Curran was fond of a challenge and would often set up walking challenges, travelling around  to  miles in a day, ldquoand think nothing of it, said Mr Statham. ldquoOne day in  he played  holes of golf in  hours.For this feat, he appeared in Ripleyrsquos Believe It Or Not!, a cartoon serialised in US newspapers from . His other appearance in the cartoon was thanks to his kicking a football  yards in bare feet.The writer stumbled across the Gala athlete by accident.ldquoI was originally researching Wyndham Halswelle, he said. ldquoHersquos in the Scottish Sports Hall of Fame, famous for having won the Olympic -metre final without running against anybody because the Americans pulled out in protest at an umpirersquos decision.ldquoHe was then shot dead in World War One.ldquoSo I was researching him but this chap Jimmy Curran kept popping up in the newspapers so I did a little bit more research and contacted one of his granddaughters, who was very helpful.Mr Statham, who lives in Newbattle, Midlothian, travelled to the States with we Janette and son Christopher, , for further research and to interview ldquomultiple people, who were either family members or trained by Jimmy.ldquoIt was a family holiday but I took two days out to visit New York Public Library and a couple of days to go to Mercersburg Academy, where I was able to dig into newspapers that arenrsquot available anywhere  in the world.ldquoThere was a lot of research done, said Mr Statham. ldquoIt was five yearsrsquo work, fitting it in around my full-time job.Curran, who died in  in Chambersburg, Pennsylvania, was inducted in the Scottish Borders Sporting Hall of Fame in , but Mr Statham believes he is otherwise little known in the land of his birth.ldquoGenerally, hersquos been forgotten. Hersquos a footnote in a few newspapers so hopefully this book will bring his story back to le again.The book, priced at pound., goes on sale this monthand can be purchased by contacting Mr Statham via email on craig.statham@btinternet

title: peebles-golf-star-craig-howie-comes-5th-uk-championship
story: BORDERS golfer Craig Howie secured fth place in the UK Championship at the weekend ndash his best performance as a professional.Playing in his fth start on the main European Tour, the -year-old from Peebles produced a rousing final-round  at The Belfry in Sutton Coldfield to finish on -.In the previous rounds, he scored , followed by a level-par  on the Friday and a fighting  in dficult conditionson the Saturday.After his stunning final round on Sunday, Howie said: ldquoThat was a brilliant last round. I went out there not expecting a lot and just went out there to have a bit of fun and to shoot a  was pretty pleasing.ldquoItrsquos the first time Irsquove been in contention on the European Tour, so it made for an exciting day.ldquoI havenrsquot really played a lot given the quarantine period and also being a Challenge Tour player, there hasnrsquot been that many events.ldquoSo, to have some time on the golf course of late has been much appreciated.ldquoThe course was still playing quite tricky on the final day and itrsquos tough to get a good score but then after a few early birdies, I managed to play a good back nine and now that I have finished top- I also get to play this week in Spain [at the Andalucia Masters].The result moves Howie up  places to th in the Race to Dubai rankings and gives him a great opportunity to gain his full European Tour card for next season.Rasmus Hoslashjgaard won The Belfry event with a score of -. Second-place went to Justin Walters, third to Martin Kaymer, fourth to Benjamin Hebert and then Howie came tied fth with Bernd Wiesberger.

title: naga-munchetty-tweets-support-girls-peebles-golf-club
story: A TV presenter has shown her support for young female golfers in Tweeddale.BBC Breakfast host Naga Munchetty retweeted a post from Peebles Golf Club ndash after more girls than boys turned up at a junior training session.Thirteen female players took part in the older junior coaching on Sunday , compared with  boys.Peebles Golf Club tweeted: "For the first time, the number of girls at our older Junior Coaching Group today exceeded the number of boys with  girls out of ."Fantastic to see the girls enjoying their golf and improving so much this season."Ms Munchetty published a love heart emoji alongside her retweet.And the young golfers also got a mention from The Jazzy Golfer on Instagram, with the sports star vowing to visit the club in the future.David Thorburn, the clubrsquos junior convenor, said: ldquoWe are delighted to see so many girls taking part in our junior coaching on a regular basis, with many now coming along for a number of years."Our aim is to make the coaching fun and inclusive, and the girls seem to enjoy the activities we put on, while playing as groups of friends."The proportion of female golfers in Scotland is fairly low at just  per cent, so hopefully Peebles can help give those numbers a boost and keep our girls playing for years to come."

title: coronavirus-melrose-rugby-club-reopen-greenyards
story: MELROSE rugby club have announced the Greenyards will reopen now that a deep-clean has been carried out.Facilities were closed and training suspended on Thursdayafter a person connected to the club tested positive for coronavirus.But this evening , the clubrsquos board announced that the Greenyards will reopen tomorrow.Melrose RFCrsquos director of safety, Jim Shepherd, said a deep-clean has been performed, with ldquoall potential contact points around the pitch disinfected.Mr Shepherd said: ldquoWe are satisfied we have done everything we can to minimise any risk of contagion.ldquoWe have carried out a full risk assessment and confirm all appropriate health and safety processes and procedures have been followed.ldquoWe take our responsibilities to our players, staff, volunteersand visitors very seriously.ldquoWe will remain vigilant and continue to take swt and decisive action to protect everyonersquos health and safety.ldquoFacilities at the Greenyards will reopen on Monday morning and training, for all age groups, will resume.

title: peebles-rugby-club-launches-poo-park-fundraiser
story: A MESSY fundraiser has been organised at the Gytes in a bid to help raise money for young people in the Borders.On Saturday, October , Peebles RFC are hosting an unusual fundraiser for Cash for Kids, and it will require a fair bit of clean-up afterwards.Until October , the club will be selling off sections of the Gytes pitch for pound a square, and on October  a sheep will be released on to the pitch and wherever it poos, the owner of that square wins a prize.Speaking on behalf of event organisers, Mark Thomson, , said: ldquoWersquove received phenomenal support so far from people in and around Peebles, and not just those associated with the rugby club."The Poo in the Park competition will see former st XV stalwart Sandy Smellie release one of his sheep onto the field on the Saturday.Mr Smellie said: "Irsquove got the perfect sheep in mind for this."Most of them are bonkers but Irsquoll be bringing down the lsquoSpecial Onersquo for this task."Donrsquot think wersquoll be waiting long!"Picture: Greig Laidlaw, Darcy Graham and Stuart Hogg with the signed Scotland shirtWhoever is lucky enough to have their square chosen by the Special One will win pound and a Scotland Rugby jersey, courtesy of Greig Laidlaw, Stuart Hogg and Darcy Graham. The shirt is signed by the Scotland team who drew - against England at Twickenham last year.Mr Thomson added: "It was a lovely gesture from Greig Laidlaw, Darcy Graham and Stuart Hogg."It adds to the incentive."Its a lovely touch, were happy they did that."Due to competition rules, the club cannot share how much money they have raised so far, but they have a target of pound,.Money raised through Poo in the Park will go towards two groups which support young people ndash one across the Borders and another closer to home in Peebles.Mr Thomson said: "Itrsquos been a real community effort and every penny raised is being match funded so people donating are helping two causes at the one time ndash helping the children that need it most across the Scottish Borders and North Northumberland and secondly, the development of youth rugby from players aged P to those in their final year at high school."The deadline for making a donation and receiving your square of the Gytes is October .To donate and for more information, visit this fundraising pageor the clubs Facebook page.

title: innerleithen-cyclists-urinating-co-op-car-park
story: CYCLISTS have been captured on CCTV urinating in a Borders car park.At a meeting of Innerleithen Community Council this month, members heard that bikers were answering naturersquos call behind the Co-op shop.Tweeddale councillor Robin Tatler said a number of issues had been raised to him by members of the public and staff at the local store, adding that he is reporting them to the police Community Action Team.Mr Tatler said: ldquoUnfortunately mountain bikers are causing all sorts of issues at the Co-op car park."They are urinating and been captured on CCTV doing it. There have also been reports of general anti-social behaviour.Councillor Stuart Bell askedthe public toilets on Hall Street had been reopened and suggested this would help solve the problem.The following day, community councillor Jackie Couchman investigated and found the toilets were an ldquoopen-and-shut case ndash although there was nothing straightforward about it, with one door marked shut which was actually open.

title: coronavirus-scotland-new-covid-rules-face-masks-workplace
story: New restrictionsfor wearing face coverings in Scotland have comeinto force today.NicolaSturgeon has announced that masks should now be worn in more public communal settings, like corridors, work canteens and break rooms.The First Minister said: "Firstly, we will introduce regulations to extend the mandatory use of face coverings in indoor communal settings."This will include, for example, staff canteens and corridors in workplaces."We will take action to strengthen compliance with the dferent strands of the FACTS advice - focusing on areas where we know from research that compliance is not yet high enough, for example, the need to self-isolate.The new restrictions on coverings came into effect todayand applyto everyone in Scotland, with exemptions.Where are face coverings mandatory A face covering is mandatory in a number of indoor settings, as well as on public transport.These include:Airline services.Amusement arcades and other leisure facilities .Aquariums, indoor zoos or visitor farms, and any other indoor tourist, heritage or cultural site.Banks, building societies and credit unions.Bars, pubs, cafes and restaurants except when an exemption applies.Bingo halls.Bowling alleys.Bus services.Bus stations, railway stationsand airports.Casinos.Cinemas.Community centres.Crematoriums and funeral directors premises.Ferry services .Indoor fitness studios, gyms, swimming pools or other indoor leisure centres.Indoor funfairs.Libraries, public reading rooms, museums and galleries.Places of worship.Post offices.Public communal settings, like corridors, work canteens and break roomsShops, takeaway restaurants, pharmacies, estate agents, beauty parlours.Storage and distribution facilities, including collection and drop off points.Taxi and private hire vehicles.Train services including the Glasgow subway and Edinburgh Tram.Who is exempt from wearing a face covering According to the Scottish Government website, there are a number of reasons to be exempt from wearing a face covering.These include:Babies, toddlers and children under  years of age.People who have a health condition or who are disabled, including hidden disabilities, for example, autism, dementia or a learning disability, or are providing care for someone with a health condition or disability, and a face covering would be inappropriate because it would cause dficulty, pain or severe distress or anxiety to the wearer or the person in the care of the wearer. This includes children with breathing dficulties and disabled children who would struggle to wear a face covering.You cannot apply a covering and wear it in the proper manner safely and consistently.Anyone who needs to take medication and cannot do so whilst wearing a face covering.A person who is communicating with someone  who relies on lip reading and facial expressions to communicate. Such people should remove the face covering only temporarily whilst communicating and replace it immediately afterwards.Anyone who is seeking medical assistance, or acting to avoid injury, illness or harm, and where wearing a face covering would make this more dficult. This also appliessomeone needs emergency assistance and they donrsquot have a face covering with them or there is not time to put one on.A person who is providing care or assistance to a vulnerable person and where wearing a face covering would make this more dficult. This also appliessomeone needs emergency assistance and they donrsquot have a face covering with them or there is not time to put one on.Exemption for couples during their indoor marriage ceremony or civil partnership registration, providing there is a partition or  metres can be maintained between the couple and other people.

title: cgi-borders-most-hi-tech-rural-area-europe
story: THE Borders has made ldquosignicant progress in becoming the most technologically advanced rural area in Europe, according to a business leader.The news comes as Scottish Borders Councilhas announced it has extended its contract with CGI, a Canadian-based IT firm, until .SBC has been working with the firm since  to digitally connect all Borders communities, with the region now closing in on becoming the UKrsquos first Smart Rural Region.Lindsay McGranaghan, CGIrsquos vice president and unit leader for Scotland, said the company is delighted to be extending its partnership with the council.:Urinating cyclists caught on CCTV behind Co-op shop in BordersMs McGranaghan said: ldquoWith the support of CGI, the Scottish Borders has already made signicant progress in becoming the most technologically advanced rural area in the UK and also Europe.ldquoTogether our vision will enhance the councilrsquos relationship with its citizens, bringing cutting edge digital solutions to provide real benefits to citizens and meet the demands of st century living.SBC and CGI plan to allow Borders residents to digitally report any issues to the council, ranging from a streetlight needing to be fixed to more major issues.:Borders woman, , starts up her own businessThere are also plans to make health and social care services more efficient with a digital system that includes features such as remote patient monitoring to identy those most in need.lsquoSmartrsquo vehicles will be introduced too, allowing the council to find out which bins need to be emptied and which do not.SBC leader Shona Haslam said: ldquoScottish Borders Council is delighted to extend CGIrsquos contract until .ldquoThis extension shows the trust we have in CGI as a valuable strategic partner, sharing our long-term commitment to providing cutting-edge digital solutions to improve our public services, benefitting the council, our community planning partners and our citizens.

title: peebles-coronavirus-volunteer-sophie-hamilton-get-honour
story: A BORDERS mum has been named in the Queenrsquos Birthday Honours list after organising crucial volunteers during the coronavirus pandemic.Sophie Hamilton, who set up the Peebles COVID- Mutual Support Group, is in line for a British Empire Medal.The support group helped to provide meals, medicine and comfort to vulnerable residents in the town during lockdown.Ms Hamilton, a mum of four, said news of her award came as a ldquototal shock."That someone had thought to nominate me came as a total surprise, she said, adding: "I didnt think I was worthy of something like that."Ms Hamilton, who also works as a community firefighter at Peebles Fire Station, said the last  months have been a ldquobusy time. Last November, she responded to the high school fire and then in March she launched the support group.:Borders could become most hi-tech rural area in Europe after council extends IT contractOn the support group, she said: "Weve been hugely busy ndash we had to respond really quickly."And she explained she could not have done any of the work alone."It has to be said this was a team effort," she said. "I may have started it, but I couldnt have done it without the team ndash they all deserve to be recognised."Ms Hamilton added that although the support group has paused some of its operations, including the phone line, volunteers remain active."Were still hereanything happens," Ms Hamilton said.:Galashiels man over the moon with honour from the QueenWhen she first created the group, Ms Hamilton used Facebook to put out a request for volunteers and supporters.Within a week, the groups page had more than , members and around  volunteers had signed up."It was really positive seeing a quick response," she said. "I think it really rekindled a sense of community spirit in the town."Not that we were lacking community spirit before, but the group helped focus it. People banded together."As well as receiving support from the local community, Ms Hamilton said her family have backed her work with the support group."My children and family have been really supportive," she said. "They didnt realise how much work it was at first but they really support me."Helping others is something which Ms Hamilton brings to all she does, and contributed to her decision to become a firefighter eight years ago.She said: "I want to help people ndash thats what I like to do."I want to be the person to help people in a physical or practical waytheyre going through something awful."[Being a firefighter] can be a physical battle but I wouldnt change a thing.":The Borders florist making people smile with a kind gestureMs Hamilton was also part of the first appliance to reach Peebles High School last November during the fire which caused extensive damage to the school."It was a huge incident to deal with," Ms Hamilton said. "We got to the gym hall and the building was glowing."We had to get out as the ceiling came in."My training kicked in but I had the additional worry having not spoken to my two children at the school to know they were OK."When the news of her award was made public last week, Ms Hamilton was on a training course with Peebles Fire Station, but she was met with a celebration when she got home."We had a mini celebration, she said. title: nicola-sturgeon-confirms-tiered-local-lockdowns-in-place-november-2
story: SCOTLANDrsquos new tiered local lockdown plan will come into force in less than two weeksapproved by parliament, the First Minister has said.Nicola Sturgeon said some areas may face stricter measures than those currently in force in the central belt, where licensed hospitality venues have been temporarily closed.She told the Scottish Governmentrsquos coronavirus briefing in Edinburgh on Tuesday that she will update the country about the temporary restrictions on hospitality businesses on Wednesday.The Cabinet will decidethese restrictions, brought in on October  to stem a rise in cases and due to end on October , will be extended until the implementation of the tiered framework.The First Minister set out the timeline for the decisions as she announced  coronavirus deaths and  positive cases were recorded in Scotland in the past  hours.Itrsquos now mandatory to wear a face covering in indoor communal workplaces in Scotland, which includes:# Canteens # Corridors# Social spacesMake sure you know where you need to wear a face covering ## https:t.co QmCaYPogpic TTTXsqgMhmdash Scottish GovernmentOctober , She told the briefing the new measures in the tiered framework,approved by MSPs, will come into effect on November  ndash aligning with the UK Governmentrsquos new furlough scheme.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoWhat that means is over the course of next week we will be assessing the up to date data and assessing whether all of the country would go into a certain level of the new framework or whether parts of the country would go into one level and other parts of the country into another.ldquoAs part of that we will be considering, of course, whether there are parts of the country that need tougher restrictions than those in place in the central belt right now, or whether there are parts of the country that might be able to have less tough restrictions.ldquoWe need to assess that on the basis of the up to date data.Under the temporary restrictions, bars and licensed restaurants in five health board areas ndash Greater Glasgow and Clyde, Lanarkshire, Ayrshire and Arran, Lothian and Forth Valley ndash have been forced to close for all but takeaway services.Pubs, bars, restaurants and cafes outside the central belt are only allowed to serve indoor customers between am and pm with a ban on alcohol inside, although alcoholic drinks can be served until pm in outdoor areas.

title: scottish-borders-council-accused-secrecy-deal
story: AN SNP councillor has criticised Scottish Borders Councilfor alleged "secret" negotiations leading to an IT contract extension until .The contract extension, between Canadian-based firm CGI and title: galashiels-heriot-watt-university-staff-vote-strike
story: STAFF at Heriot-Watt University, which has a Galashiels campus, have backed strike action in response to plans to axe  jobs.Scottish members of the University and College Union overwhelmingly voted in favour of industrial action during a ballot, with  per cent of participants supporting a strike.The ballot, which received a  per cent turnout, was in response to the universityrsquos proposals to cut  jobs.These new cuts would add to the  staff job losses in , with the university refusing to rule out compulsory redundancies.: Borders could become most hi-tech rural area in Europe after council extends IT contractUCU Scotland official Mary Senior said: ldquoBy voting in these numbers UCU members at Heriot-Watt University have made it crystal clear today that they have no confidence in the universityrsquos plans to cut jobs."The ballot result is a clear mandate for industrial action and to oppose job cuts.ldquoThe employer has made good progress on seeking volunteers and should now take compulsory redundancies off the table, to give staff some job security and stability, and students the reassurances they need on the learning environment.: Total shock: Borders mum to get honour from Queen for coronavirus effortsldquoItrsquos not too late for the university to avoid strike action but they need to act now.The Border reported in September that staff were considering taking industrial action over the suggested cuts.The union said plans to cut jobs have been rushed, with alternative cost-cutting measures not properly explored.Following previous cuts, the union has warned that losing more staff will impact ldquoboth the student experience and the universityrsquos reputation.

title: drink-driver-six-times-limit-borders-golf-weekend
story: A MOTORIST who claimed he had stopped drinking  hours previously was still found to be almost six times the legal alcohol limit when police came across him on a Borders road.David Proudfoot, , had been drinking heavily at a golf weekend and had been heading home along the A at Ashkirk on the evening of Sunday, September , when he gave a reading of  microgrammes - the legal limit being .Selkirk Sherf Court was told Proudfoot had played  holes of golf over two days in warm weather and had been drinking "to the extreme" but had stopped drinking during the early hours of Sunday morning.But on the Sunday evening at around pm - around  hours later - he still gave the reading of six times the legal alcohol limit.Sherf Peter Paterson expressed incredulity at the explanation and said he would be surprisedProudfoot would "have been able to see the ball" during Sundays round of golf due to the level of alcohol he had consumed.Proudfoot, of Falcon Court, Edinburgh, was fined pound, and banned from driving for  months.

title: coronavirus-nicola-sturgeon-extends-lockdown-rules-five-tier-system-november-2
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has extended the temporary lockdown restrictions in Scotland for another week.At her daily briefing in Edinburgh, the First Minister said the current rules would be rolled on until am November  ndash when a new tiered system will likely come into force.Under the current restrictions, bars and licensed restaurants in five health board areas ndash Greater Glasgow and Clyde, Lanarkshire, Ayrshire and Arran, Lothian and Forth Valley ndash have been forced to close for all but takeaways.Pubs, bars, restaurants and cafes where in Scotland are only allowed to serve indoor customers between am and pm with a ban on alcohol inside, although alcoholic drinks can be served until pm in outdoor areas.Current restrictions are in place in the central beltMs Sturgeon said: "This is first and foremost a public health decision.ldquoAlthough we have grounds for cautious optimism that the restrictions are having an effect, the clinical advice to Cabinet is that it would not be safe to lt them as early as Monday.ldquoThe extension allows us to transition to the new levels system from November .The current rules also include a ban on household visits.Snooker and pool halls, indoor bowling alleys, casinos and bingo halls will also remain closed, and contact sports for people aged  and over will also remain suspended with an exception of professional sports.Gyms and pools can remain open for inidual exercise, but indoor group activities are not allowed for people over .What is the new system It is understood the new system, which is due to start on November , would have three central tiers akin to the medium, high and very high alert levels in England, which curb hospitality and social mixing.However, there would also be an extra upper and lower level.The lowest would be as close to normality as possible in the absence of a vaccine, while the topmost tier would involve extreme restrictions, including travelbans.Closing schools and switching to home-based "blended learning" would always be a last resort.But there is not yet clarity on exactly what the public could expect in each tier.Under current proposals it is not thought any area will be placed onto the top tier straight away, but central belt areas already facing tighter restrictions are likely to be put into the second-top category when the system is brought in on November .Watch FM title: clocks-change-weekend-daylight-saving-time-ends
story: Itll be an extra hour in bed this weekend as daylight saving time comes to an end.Scots will have to change their clocks on Sunday, and well begin to see lighter mornings and darker evenings.Well be moving backby one hour on Sunday, October  at am.The clock reversal happens every year on the last Sunday of October, pushing the UK back into Greenwich Mean Time .What do you need to do Most devices such as phones, computers, laptops and televisions will change automatically, so no need to worry about those.Analog clocks and clocks on appliances such as microwaves and ovens will have to be changed manually.Why does this happen The change was introduced back in  in an effort to save energy and help the war effort during the First World War.The Summer Time Act  advanced the clocks by one hour from May  until October .When do they change again GMT ends in the spring when we go back to BST.In , GMT ends on Sunday, March  to mark the lsquoofficialrsquo start of summer.

title: make-annual-leave-christmas
story: As wersquore fast approaching the festive period, many of us are needing the break more than ever.While Christmas may not be the same as years gone by, with National Clinical Director Jason Leitch stating that ldquoChristmas is not going to be normal and that ldquopeople should get their digital Christmas ready, one thing that Covid- canrsquot take away is our love for the yule-tide season.Whether it will be drinking mulled wine at home, heading to the online Christmas markets or having the office party over Zoom  - wersquoll all be doing our best to make the festivities feel as normal as possible.If you want to take full advantage of the break, then thanks to this handy loophole you could have  days off by only using three days of your annual leave.Sounds too good to be true, right  Well in fact itrsquos completely true.Herersquos what you need to knowThis year, Christmas Day and New Years Day fall on a Friday, so your bank holidays will get transferred over to the following Monday.This means that you will be off from Friday  December to Tuesday  December and Friday  January to Tuesday  January.Soyou take off Tuesday  December - Thursday  December then you will be off work for a whole eleven days.This is how your calendar would look.Friday th December - Christmas DaySaturday th December - Boxing Day Sunday th December - WeekendMonday th December - Boxing Day bank holiday Tuesday th December - Take annual leaveWednesday th December - Take annual leaveThursday st December - Take annual leaveFriday st January  - New Yearrsquos DaySaturday nd January - WeekendSunday rd January - WeekendMonday th January - nd January bank holiday Tuesday th January - Back to work

title: working-home-claim-125-hmrc-cant-work-office
story: HMRC havelaunched a new tool tohelp those working from home claim back additional expenses.Weve put together all you need to know on how it works and how to checkyoure eligible.How much could you claim backyoure required to work from home According to HMRC, employees can claim tax relief based on the rate of tax they pay - and you could recoup up to pound per year.Details on Gov.uk state:ldquoYou may be able to claim tax relief for additional household costsyou have to work at home on a regular basis, either for all or part of the week."This includesyou have to work from home because of coronavirus .However -you cannot claim tax reliefyou choose to work from home.Additional costs include things such as heating, metered water bills, home contents insurance, business calls or a new broadband connection.They do not include costs that would stay the same whether you were working at home or in an office, such as mortgage interest, rent or council tax.When did the HMRC online portal launch The online portallaunched onOctober .How much can I get You can either claim tax relief on:pound a week from April , - you will not need to keep evidence of your extra costsThe exact amount of extra costs yoursquove incurred above the weekly amount - yoursquoll need evidence such as receipts, bills or contracts.Those paying the standard tax rate of  per cent, can claim pound. per week , while those paying the higher rate of  per cent, can claim pound. per week.Additional rate taxpayers who pay  per cent can claim pound. a week.How to checkyoureeligible and claim tax reliefTo checkyoursquore eligible,use the online tool on the Gov.uk website.HMRC havesaid you can claim tax relief from the date you began working from home.If your application is approved, then your online portal will adjust your tax code for the  to  tax year.You will then receive the tax relief directly through your salary and this will continue until March .HMRCrsquos interim director general of customer services, Karl Khan, said:ldquoWe want everyone to get the money that they are entitled to, so wersquove made the online service as easy to use as we can - it takes just a few minutes to make a claim.

title: royal-mail-launch-new-doorstep-parcel-pick-up-service-across-uk
story: Royal Mail have announced a brand new service where postmen and women will pick up parcels from the doorsteps of peoplersquos homes across the UK.Weve put together everything you need to know.How will the new service work Households that have packages they need to send can now do so without leaving home for a p charge per parcel, Royal Mail said.The parcels can weigh up to kg and can be a little over twice the size of most airplane hand luggage .It was hailed by the postal service as ldquoone of the biggest changes to the daily delivery since the launch of the post box in .Customers will be able to get their parcels collected every day apart from Sundays.Pre-paidpackages can be collected for p per item.The company has been testing its system in the west of England, but will now roll it out nationwide, it said on Wednesday .What have Royal Mail said about the changes Royal Mail chief commercial officer Nick Landon said:ldquoRoyal Mail Parcel Collect is a fantastic step forward for all of our customers."It makes it easier to use our services than ever before."Changes toservices in recent yearsReturns have become an increasingly important market for the postal system in recent years, as online shoppers want the chance to change the items they bought.It has spawned a new industry of companies to take charge of the s process.Millionaire businessman Lloyd Dorfman has set up Doddle, a company that partners with local shops to simply s, but also offers click-and-collect services.Royal Mail has been forced to rely increasingly on parcels, as letters drop in importance with the advent of email. Since  the number of letters it delivers has halved, even before the pandemic.This year has been particularly harsh. In the three months to the end of June the company delivered  million fewer letters than the same period the year before, down  per cent.The reduction was sped up by Covid-, but even before the pandemic hit, Royal Mail was expecting a drop of up to eight per cent in letter volumes during the  months to the end of March.Meanwhile, parcel volumes have increased greatly.The company has already tried to maximise its presence in the booming parcel market, launching parcel post boxes last year. The first parcel post service was launched in in .

title: 4-mouth-watering-recipes-make-pumpkin-halloween
story: Carving pumpkins has becomean annual tradition to mark Halloween on October  each year -with people lighting up their spooky creations on the night.However, the activity is now so popular that the UK is expected to waste about , tonnes of perfectly edible pumpkin this Halloween ndash but the leftovers can be put to good use.How to reduce pumpkin wasteInstead of throwing out your pumpkin innards once you have finished carving, there are a number of ways you can use your leftovers to help reduce the amount of waste.Weve put togethersome tasty ideas to tryyoursquore looking for inspiration.Pumpkin seed browniesJohn Quigley of Red Onion in Glasgow providedthisrecipe to Zero Waste Scotland.Ingredients:bull g dark chocolate, minimum % cocoa, chopped into small piecesbull g unsalted butterbull g plain flourbull  eggsbull frac vanilla pod, seeds onlybull g soft brown sugarbull g pumpkin seeds, rinsed and left to dryMethod:Toast the pumpkin seeds on a baking tray for - minutes at #C gas mark , set aside to cool.Place the butter and half of the dark chocolate in a bowl and melt together using a bain-marie or microwave.Mix the egg and vanilla together, then add the sugar. Add to the melted butter and chocolate.St in the flour and fold through gently until just combined.Add the remaining chocolate pieces and mix well.Pour into a lined, cm square baking tray and top with the toasted pumpkin seeds.Reduce the oven down to #C gas mark  and bake the brownies for  minutes. If the middle is still wobbly, place back in the oven until just set.Remove from the oven and allow to cool completely before turning out and cutting into squares.Sausage, Apple and Pumpkin BakeTop chef Neil Forbes has shared thisrecipe for a sausage, apple and pumpkin bake.Ingredients:bull Allow three sausages per person bull  medium-sized onions, roughly choppedbull a splash of cold-pressed rapeseed oilbull salt and pepperbull frac pumpkin , roughly choppedbull a few par-boiled potatoes , cut into large chunksbull a knob of butterbull  clove garlic, slicedbull  very large cooking apple , cored and roughly choppedbull a small handful of fennel fronds, roughly choppedbull a sprig of rosemaryMethod:Heat the oil in a large casserole dish or oven-proof pan, and fry the onions and whole sausages. Season with salt and pepper.Add the pumpkin to the pan. Keep stirring and moving the dish around to get colour on all the ingredients. Then add the potatoes, butter, garlic and apples.Make sure everything is starting to colour nicely before placing in the oven for  to  minutes at C Gas Mark  to cook further and brown.Remove from the oven, add the fennel fronds and stir. Serve at the table in the dish you cooked it in ndash no time for pretty presentation here.Pumpkin soupChef Tom Kitchin has suggested this recipe for roasted pumpkin soup.Ingredients:For the stockbull Trimmings and skin from the pumpkinbull ml chicken stockbull  large onion, peeledbull  bunch parsley stalksbull - sprigs of thymebull  cinnamon stick head of garlicbull  celery sticks, roughly choppedbull  carrots, roughly chopped salt and pepperFor the soupbull pumpkin, peeled and cut into  equal wedgesbull  tbsp vegetable oilbull  large onion, peeled and thinly slicedbull  teaspoons ground cinnamonbull  tsp caraway seedsbull  tbsp butterbull  tbsp clear honeybull ml cream salt and pepperMethod:To make the stock, put all the pumpkin skin and trimmings into a large pot and cover with chicken stock. Keep the pumpkin seeds back for roasting.Add the rest of the stock ingredients and simmer slowly for at least one hour.Leave to rest for  minutes and then strain through a sieve.To make the soupDivide the pumpkin wedges into two batches. One batch is for roasting and the other for sweating on top of the stove.Chop the wedges for sweating into cm cubes and set aside. Heat the oil in a large, heavy-bottomed pot over a medium heat.Add the onion,  teaspoon of cinnamon and a good pinch of salt, then sweat gently until the onion is very soft.Add the cubes of pumpkin and cook gently until soft. Add enough stock to cover and leave to simmer.Meanwhile, heat a large frying pan and add the butter. When it begins to foam, put in the large pumpkin wedges, salt and pepper. Allow the pumpkin to colour on both sidesand then sprinkle on  teaspoon of cinnamon and  teaspoon of caraway seeds.Continue to cook, turning occasionally to ensure that they are an even colour. After about  minutes, add the honey and put the pumpkin into the oven at C F Gas Mark  and roast for six to eight minutes until it is dark golden brown.Add the roasted pumpkin to the pot of simmering pumpkin and mix together well, adding more stocknecessary.Leave to cook until the pumpkin is very soft and tender, then add the cream. Check the seasoning and take off heat.Leave to rest for ten minutes before transferring it to a blender and blitzing until smooth. The key to a great soup is a good stock.Or how about a Harry Potter-inspired recipeFinally, Edinburgh chef Mark Greenaway has created thissweet and savoury recipe after being inspired by Harry Potter and The Philosopherrsquos Stone by JK Rowling.Ingredients:bull g puff pastrybull  chicken leg, roasted, meat pickedbull  new potatoes, diced and boiledbull  carrot, diced and boiledbull g roasted pumpkinbull g caster sugarbull seeds of  vanilla podbull ml double creambull  beaten eggMethod:Combine the chicken, potato and carrots in a bowl.Blend the pumpkin, sugar, vanilla and cream, then pass this mixture through a fine sieve and chill in the fridge.Preheat the oven to C Gas Mark . Roll the pastry and cut out two circles roughly cm in diameter.Place the chicken mixture on one half of each pastry circle, then place the sweet pumpkin mixture on the other half. Fold each circle over to create a pasty shape using egg wash on the edges to seal it.Crimp the top with your fingers and brush with egg wash all over. Bake for  minutes.

title: borders-edition-bbc-debate-night-show-gets-postponed
story: THE Borders episode of BBC Scotlandrsquos Debate Night has been pushed back, meaning there is still time for Borderers to be part of the show.Initially scheduled for October , the Borders edition of the popular topical programme, hosted by journalist Stephen Jardine, will now be aired on November .The BBC is giving people the chance to apply to be part of the live virtual audience, with opportunities to ask the showrsquos guests questions.Those interested are asked to fill out an application form that includes fields such as party allegiance and the subject they wish to discuss with the .:lsquoWe have no secretsrsquo ndash Council rejects criticism of -year IT contractThe successful applicants will be in a position to field a question to some of Scotlandrsquos key politicians and public figures.The  has yet to be announced for the November show.The application form reads: ldquoTo take part you will need access to a smartphone, tablet or laptop or desktop computer and have a reliable internet connection."You will need to be available for no more than two hours on the evening of the programme for which you are applying.Applicants are chosen for a range of factors, such as voting history, views on big issues like EU membership and independence, gender, economic and ethnic background.

title: coronavirus-nicola-sturgeons-five-tier-lockdown-system-explained
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has today set out Scotlands new five-tier local lockdown system.The new set of restrictions has been anticipated since a similar three-tiered system was introduced in England by Prime Minister Boris Johnson.If approved at Holyrood next week, the new measures will come into force in Scotland on Monday, November .The three middle tiers will be broadly similar to the English system - with Scotland also introducing a more extreme tier akin to a "fuller lockdown", as well as a lower level with "slightly more freedoms".The First Minister said the decision on what level will apply to each area will be discussed in coming days and reviewed weekly.Here, we set out what the five tiers mean and what we know so far:Level Nicola Sturgeon said Level  is "broadly comparable" to the position reached in Scotland in August "when the virus was very suppressed, but still a threat."She added:"At this level, we would be able to meet indoors with  people from  households. And most businesses would be open, albeit with safety measures in place."Level At Level  there is slightly more restrictions - with indoor household meetings reducing to six people from two households.However she hopes there will still be a "reasonable degree of normality".The First Minister said: "This is similar to the situation we were at in mid September, as cases started to rise again but prevalence was still fairly low."" alt"Border : -day positive rate per , population " class"editor-image"-day positive rate per , population Level The First Minister said "Levels  and  are intended to apply at times such as now, when transmission is higher and rising."She said: "Level  entails restrictions broadly similar to those currently in place just now outside the central belt ndash with limitations on hospitality and no gatherings in peoplersquos homes."Currentlypubs, bars, restaurants and cafes where in Scotland are only allowed to serve indoor customers between am and pm with a ban on alcohol inside, although alcoholic drinks can be served until pm in outdoor areas.Level Level  is broadly similar to the tougher restrictions which currently apply across the central belt, with much of hospitality being closed completely.Since October , bars and licensed restaurants in five health board areas ndash Greater Glasgow and Clyde, Lanarkshire, Ayrshire and Arran, Lothian and Forth Valley ndash have been forced to close for all but takeaways.Ms Sturgeon added: "There are however some key dferences ndash for example we envisage restaurants being able to open, at least partially, in Level ."Levels  and  are intended to apply for relatively short periods ot time to bring transmission under control."Level The First Minister said restrictions at Level  are "closer to a full lockdown", with things like non-essential shops being closed.She said: "We would not use [Level ] unless absolutely necessary ndash would apply when transmission rates are or threatening to become very high, with corresponding pressure on the NHS.""However even under level  restrictions,  people from up to  households could still meet outdoors there would be no limit on outdoor exercise for iniduals and manufacturing and construction businesses would stay open, with safety measures in place.""In other words, we do not envisage ing to a situation as severe as the first lockdown."" alt"Border : Positive cases in Scotland " class"editor-image"Positive cases in Scotland What about schools The First Minister said the "objective at all levelsis,as far as possible, to keep schools open - though with necessary safety measures in place."That is in the best interests of children and young people."What about those who are shielding The First Minister says anoyone who is shielding should continue to follow the general public advice.However she added: "Todayrsquos publication also provides additional advice for each level of restrictions - for activities like going to work, school, shopping and having contact with others."You will find this advice in the framework itself, and the CMO is sending you a letter today."You can follow this advice to the letteryou want to. Howeveryou want to understand the evidence, and take informed decisions, we will shortly be publishing a guide to help you to do that."The First Minister also pointed people towards the National Helpline foradvice and support ndash the number is   .When will the full guidance be published Nicola Sturgeon says full details will appear on the gov.scotwebsite today.

title: home-bargains-launch-aldi-inspired-system-within-stores
story: Discount retailer Home Bargains haveintroduced a new Aldi-inspired traffic-light systemto help control the number of shoppers in its branches across the UK.Heres everything you need to know.What new system are Home Bargains rolling out The companyhopesthe traffic-light prompting system willensure thatcustomers socially distance inside all of its  stores nationwide.Earlier this year, German-ownedsupermarket chain Aldi launched a similar system in their branches throughout the UK to keep staff and shoppers safe.How will the new system work The new lights are sensor-controlled and placed at the entrance and exit points of stores to monitor how many people are in the shop.Customers will be allowed to enter Home Bargains stores when the lights turn green.Hitachirsquos D LiDAR Motion Sensor system will be used, which can monitor, in real-time, the number of people shopping in-store.In addition to people counting, the sophisticated sensor will also be able totrack a customerrsquos journey around a store by directly detecting human shape and movement, identying where they stopped and who they passed by.According to Retail Systems, the technology will monitor shoppers without privacy invasion, as unlike CCTV cameras, the sensor does not collect personal information.What have bosses of Home Bargains said about the move Joe Morris, of TJ Morris, the firm behind Home Bargains, said: "Over the past few months, retail environments have changed, and wersquove had to quickly adapt to new ways of operating."New, innovative technologies have played a signicant part in us still being able to provide a safe and pleasant shopping experience for our customers."

title: scottish-borders-chamber-commerce-gets-new-chairwoman
story: SCOTTISH Borders Chamber of Commercehas appointed a new chairwoman, along with three new directors.Lee-Anne Gillie, a business consultant who helps Borders firms with sales growth, takes over from Moira Wilson as chairwoman of SBCC.Ms Gillie said: ldquoItrsquos a privilege to be entrusted with the position of chair.ldquoWe are fortunate to have an incredibly erse range of businesses across the region, and while we are likely to face a great number of challenges in this ever-changing COVID world, the people and the businesses within the area have always been resilient.ldquoItrsquos our duty now more than ever to represent their needs and to provide a  to showcase what they can offer locally and further afield.:lsquoWe have no secretsrsquo ndash Council rejects criticism of -year IT contractThe chamber acts as a voice for members concerns, liaising closely with MPs, MSPs and local councillors, as well as providing networking opportunities and informing members of crucial information.Ms Gillie started her career with Peri-Dent in Galashiels in , before joining RP Adam Ltd in .Following its acquisition by Ecolab in , Ms Gillie oversaw the business integration and lsquochange management processrsquo, among other areas.SBCC has also appointed three new directors - Giles Etherington, Alan Wheelans and Tim Ferguson - as the body looks to ldquomaximise its potential.Mr Etherington, owner of Melrose-based Brand Satellite, says it is their ambition to make the chamber ldquoa lsquomust joinrsquo for every Scottish Borders business.:Doddie Weir whisky auction set to help rugby legends MND foundationMeanwhile, Mr Ferguson, managing director of Ferguson Planning in Galashiels, set up his business during the last recession and says it is important to look ldquoforward not back.ldquoThe Borders is at a critical junction in terms of how we react, plan and attract new investment to the region, he said.ldquoWe must do all we can to encourage ersication and maximise emerging markets, playing to our strengths and promoting the Borders across the UK as a great place to live and do business.And Mr Wheelans, managing director of Selkirk-based Border Safeguard Limited, says it is a ldquoprivilege to be joining the chamber.The recently appointed interim CEO, Emily McGowan, says the appointment of the new additions is ldquoa positive step.ldquoAt such a crucial time, they will play a signicant role in supporting our chamber and enabling it to maximise its potential, and in turn, the potential of our member businesses, she said.

title: a6091-melrose-bypass-shut-three-nights
story: THE Melrose bypass will close overnight for three days next month.A half-kilometre stretch of the A, near the Borders General Hospital, is getting resurfaced.The bypass, which runs between Melrose and Galashiels, will shut from pm to am on November ,  and .A ersion route will be signposted via the A, A and A, adding approximately  miles and  minutes to affected journeys.Tommy Deans, BEAR Scotlandrsquos south east network manager, said: ldquoThese surfacing improvements will help to address the defects on this section of the A and will greatly improve the experience for motorists.ldquoIt is essential that we close the road during these works to ensure the safety of road workers and motorists, however wersquove arranged for the project to take place overnight to minimise the impact."Emergency services will be able to use the closed routes and local residents who live along the closure will be given access when safe to do so.

title: coronavirus-borders-guest-house-gets-booking-hotspot
story: A BORDERS guest house has received an apology from Booking after originally being warned of a finethe guest house rejected people from an English coronavirus hotspot.Steve and Lisa Davies, owners of Caddon View in Innerleithen, got a booking from a Sheffield couple two days before South Yorkshire was to go into the strictest level of Englandrsquos local lockdown system.Alarmed by the potential health risk, Mr and Mrs Davies tried to get the booking cancelled ndash but booking agent Booking initially refused to help.In an interview with the Border , Mr Davies, , said he felt "utterly powerless" and that people who were "not doing the right thing" were being prioritised over a small business "trying to do the right thing".He added: "Were not being dficult, were just trying to look after people.":Galashiels boxer to fight for world title in real-le Rocky storyAccording to UK Government data, Sheffieldrsquos rate of new cases was . per , population between October -.A hotspot is defined by Imperial College London researchers as a council area with a rate of more than  new cases per , per week.The rate in the Borders, between October -, was . cases.Mr Davies told the Border he had spent  minutes on the phone with Booking on Thursday , appealing for the booking to be cancelled.But Mr Davies said he found himself ldquogoing around in circles and resorted to sending links to the booking agent to explain that Sheffield was going into lsquoTier rsquo of lockdown from .am on Saturday .Even then, Mr Davies said he was informed that he would be chargedalternative accommodation had to be found for the Sheffield couple.Under Tier , people are banned from meeting other households indoors, with pubs having to shut unless they sell lsquosubstantial mealsrsquo. People are advised against travel outside a Tier  area, unless for work or caring responsibilities.Eventually, Booking apologised to Mr Davies and cancelled the reservation.Mr Davies told the Border his business only received the booking on Wednesday evening, and when he spoke with one of the guests over the phone, the person was ldquoblatant about knowingly trying to avoid lockdown.Mr Davies said the prospective guest revealed the couple had no intention of spending their holiday in the Borders, but that they were "escaping lockdown" before travelling "further north" for the rest of their break."Its utterly cavalier to come here," Mr Davies said.A spokesperson for Booking said: "At Booking, the health and safety of our customers and partners is of the utmost concern."We are continuing to monitor the COVID- situation worldwide, including newly imposed local restrictions, so we can help support those impacted in the best possible way."We have apologised to this partner for any confusion caused, and have confirmed that they will not be charged for booking in question, which has now been cancelled."

title: moon-news-nasa-make-announcement-new-discovery
story: Nasa is to make an announcement about an "exciting new discovery" about the moon today.The space agency said the discoveryldquocontributes to Nasarsquos efforts to learn about the moon in support of deep space exploration.They teased the news last week, and it has led to speculation by social media users.But we will finally get to hear the news today - heres everything we know so far.When will the moon announcement be made The news will be broadcast live at pm EDT on Monday - which is pm in Greenwich Mean Time.How can I watch the Nasa conference There are a number of ways to watch the announcement live.Nasa is making people aware of its live stream, which can be accessed hereand will broadcast the media teleconference live.You can also head over to Nasa TV on YouTubeand check their Twitter for updates.Who will be at the conference Paul Hertz, astrophysics ision director at NASA Headquarters, WashingtonJacob Bleacher, chief exploration scientist for the Human Exploration and Operations Mission Directorate at NASA HeadquartersCasey Honniball, postdoctoral fellow at NASArsquos Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, MarylandNaseem Rangwala, project scientist for the SOFIA mission, NASArsquos Ames Research Center, Silicon Valley, CalorniaWhat has Nasa said Nasa announced on Wednesday that it had an "exciting" new discovery about the moon from the Stratospheric Observatory for Infrared Astronomy .The discovery contributes to their efforts to learn about the moon in support of "deep space exploration".What could be announced People have been speculating the dferent things that may be announced.Some have said that, because Dr Honniball will be in attendance, it could relate to the presence of water on the moon.However, it is not yet clear.

title: stephen-winyard-stobo-chairman-dedicates-mbe-staff
story: A BORDERS businessman recognised in the Queenrsquos Birthday Honours list has dedicated the award to his workforce.Stephen Winyard, chairman of Stobo Castle Health Spa, Peeblesshire, will receive an MBE for services to business and the community in Peeblesshire.Mr Winyard, , says it is the latter of the two that means the most to him, describing the community as ldquoeverything.ldquoAny sort of honour is a reflection of the work that we do, he said. ldquoWith services to business, yes we run a good business, but what is more important to me is the services to the local community.ldquoI am incredibly proud of the amazing team at Stobo, -strong. Only through their dedication and hard work are we in the position to support the local community and fulfil our position of social responsibility."I take no plaudits personallyMr Winyard found out about the honour in May, but the official announcement was delayed until October due to the coronavirus pandemic.Asked whether he has found time to celebrate, he said: ldquoNot at all. It is not a celebration for me, it is a celebration for an incredible team we have at Stobo.ldquoI take no plaudits personally. This MBE is a tribute for everyone who works at Stobo.Mr Winyard became chairman in , stepping away from his role as managing director of the business.That role is now occupied by his eldest son, one of four family members he works with.Mr Winyard described working with his we and three children as ldquoincredibly satisfying.ldquoSometimes people in family businesses fall out with each other but the five of us are very, very close and support each other, he said. ldquoThe future of Stobo is in far safer hands now than when I was in charge.Stobo Castle flying the Olympic flag back in Stobo closed in March due to the pandemic, a situation that Mr Winyard described as ldquopretty grim.However, the team at Stobo used the unusual circumstances to refurbish areas of the site.Mr Winyard says his ldquomain focus is now keeping the team at Stobo together.ldquoMy focus over the last few months has been to ensure as far as possible that our -strong workforce stays intact, he said. title: man-oldest-scot-get-phd-books-borders-sites
story: A MAN who has penned books on Borders landmarks is thought to be the oldest Scottish recipient of a PhD.Alastair Maxwell-Irving, who has researched and written two books on Border tower houses, became a doctor of philosophy after passing his PhD viva over Zoom, two days after his th birthday.The retired engineer has spent decades studying historical architecture, with the award of the PhD from Glasgow Caledonian Universitymade in recognition of a letime of historical research.:Professor hopes DNA test will show link to remarkable Borders man"People ask me what Im going to do with a PhD at  years old but I have plenty of other projects to keep me occupied, said Dr Maxwell-Irving, of Stirling.ldquoIt is the culmination of many years of research on a subject that has fascinated me since childhood."I love the countryside and for years spent most of my weekends visiting sites, photographing them, and taking notes - through summer, winter, snow, and sunshine."Everyone at GCU has been so helpful, I cant thank them enough. The award is truly an honour.":Coronavirus: Borders guest house distressed by booking from English hotspotMr Maxwell-Irving is GCUrsquos oldest graduate.He has served as an honorary assistant with the Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments of Scotland in his spare time for more than  years.The dean of GCUrsquos School for Business and Society, professor John Lennon, said: "Achieving a PhD at any age is a triumph but this is a truly exceptional case and reaffirms our view that higher education should be accessible to all irrespective of age or any other factors."We are so pleased Dr Alastair Maxwell-Irving chose GCU and my thanks to the supervisory team and academics involved in this noteworthy process.ldquoHeartfelt congratulations from myself and all at GCU.

title: coronavirus-borders-eyed-tier-2-local-lockdown
story: THE Scottish Government is planning to place the Borders in Tier  of the local lockdown system, according to Shona Haslam.Mrs Haslam, the Conservative leader of Scottish Borders Council, is seeking more information about how decisions are being made, adding that Tier  could be the ldquoworst case scenario for businesses.In a press release issued today , Mrs Haslam said: ldquoThe Scottish Government must provide clear answers to the people of the Scottish Borders before I can agree to any tiering designation for the Scottish Borders.ldquoWithout this transparency it is incredibly dficult to understand what the SNP Government is doing and how they are taking their decisions.The Scottish Government will introduce the five-tier system on November , with Tier  seeing the most relaxed rules and Tier  having the strictest.In Tier , visiting other households indoors is banned. Meanwhile, pubs can serve alcohol indoors with a main meal.Six people from two households are allowed to meet outdoors and in hospitality settings.However, Mrs Haslam believes Tier  could prove to be a ldquohammer blow to local businesses.In her statement, she writes: ldquoWith low rates per ,, good NHS capacity and no community transition, I need certainty that Tier  is the correct tier for the Scottish Borders.ldquoBeing in Tier  has the potential to be the worst case scenario, it would be a hammer blow to local businesses already feeling the economic strain of the pandemic.ldquoIf we were in Tier  business would be getting support as they would have to close,we were in Tier  then businesses could stay open and stay viable.ldquoI am really concerned that being in Tier  with the current restrictions on hospitality but with no support will be disastrous for local business.ldquoOver the next few days I will be having conversations with the Scottish Government with regards to this tiering system.ldquoI will be arguing for clear evidence as to why we are in Tier  and business support for those businesses affected.Mrs Haslam, who represents Tweeddale East, has sent the Scottish
